Award.AbstractNarration:
This travel grant provides partial support for U.S. participation in the Young Topologists Meeting 2016, held at the University of Copenhagen, Denmark, July 4th-8th, 2016. The Young Topologists Meeting (YTM) is an annual European conference focused on the work of graduate students and young researchers in topology, that brings in participants from all over the world. At the YTM, junior topologists present their work to a large international audience, and also attend mini-courses taught by senior topologists. The conference provides opportunities for the participants to meet new colleagues and mentors, and to form research collaborations. Its open and supportive atmosphere encourages young mathematicians, including those from underrepresented groups, to pursue research careers in topology.

The YTM is an annual event, first started in 2007, and alternating between Copenhagen, Denmark and Lausanne, Switzerland. The conference features parallel sessions of contributed talks by graduate students and young researchers, covering a broad spectrum of topics in topology. In addition to these talks, there will be mini-courses by three senior topologists, discussing the connections between algebraic topology and other fields, including representation theory and K-theory, geometric topology, and mathematical physics. This year Akhil Mathew (Harvard University, US) will give a course on Mackey structure and algebraic K-theory. Oscar Randall-Williams (Cambridge University, UK) and Nathalie Wahl (University of Copenhagen, Denmark) will give courses on homological stability, diffeomorphism groups, cobordism categories, and topological field theories. The conference web page is available at http://www.math.ku.dk/english/research/conferences/2016/ytm2016/

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant provided funding for graduate students and young researchers at US institutions to attend the Young Topologists Meeting (YTM) 2016 in Copenhagen, Denmark. The Young Topologists Meeting (YTM) is an annual conference focusing on the scientific work of graduate students and young researchers in topology. It is the largest annual conference for young topologists in Europe, hosting a total of 183 participants in 2016. This grant funded travel for 23 students, bringing the number of US participants at the conference to 34. In addition, 11 of the 34 graduate student talks at the YTM 2016 were given by students at US institutions, 8 of which were funded through this grant.

The YTM 2016 brought together graduate students and young researchers in topology from all over the world. Countries other than the USA represented at this conference included Denmark, Germany, France, UK, Sweden, Norway, Italy, Spain, Switzerland, Poland, Turkey, Russia, China, and India. This grant has therefore helped young topologists from the US to connect with an international community of their peers, exchange knowledge and broaden each other's horizons.

One of the major outcomes of YTM is that participants make research connections and develop friendly relationships with their future colleagues. The open and supportive atmosphere of the YTM creates space for students to ask questions and participate. It gives the speakers an ideal setting in which to present their work to a large audience, often for the first time. It also helps young researchers find mentors outside their existing circles, and helps new PhDs with career transitions at a critical point. Many collaborations -- both peer-to-peer and junior-to-mentor -- have been born at YTM.

Finally, the YTM features mini-courses that offer introductions into subfields of topology by three experts in the field, serving as a gateway into these fields for even the relatively inexperienced participants. The first mini-course in 2016 described the theory of induction and restriction, or Mackey structure. It reviewed the classical applications of this theory to group cohomology and representation theory, and described how modern formulations of Mackey structure can advance our understanding of algebraic K-theory. The second and third courses discussed recent advances and new directions in cobordism categories, topological field theories, and homological stability. These areas have been very productive since Madsen and Weiss’ resolution of the Mumford conjecture, and have given advances in our understanding of diffeomorphism groups of manifolds and of the moduli space of surfaces. In total, the three courses have given the next generation of topologists insight into how their field can inform representation theory and K-theory, geometric topology, and mathematical physics.
